Project Description  The solar project entails the construction of a 55 megawatt peak 
(MWp)  solar  generation  plant  in  Central  Thailand  (73 MWp  gross 
capacity). Its development and implementation will be covered by a 5-
year automatically renewable power purchase agreement between 
the  Electricity  Generating  Authority  of  Thailand  (EGAT)  and  NED 
under the Small Power Producers Program. EGAT will purchase all 
the energy output of the plant up to 55 MW, the upper limit set in the 
power  purchase  agreement.  The  solar  project  will  use  innovative 
thin-film photovoltaic technology and is expected to be one of the 
largest solar photovoltaic projects in the world. It is also working with 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to prefinance certified emission 
reductions under ADB’s Carbon Market Initiative.  
   
Implementation  The project will use thin-film photovoltaic technology produced by 
Arrangements  Sharp,  and  will  be  implemented  by  Sharp  and  the  Italian-Thai 
Development  Public  Company  under  a  fixed-price,  date-certain 
engineering,  procurement,  and  construction  contract  with 
performance  guarantees  for  on-time  completion  and  a  25-year 
performance warranty for the photovoltaic module. Among the world’s 
largest  suppliers  of  solar  cells,  Sharp  holds  about  20%  of  the 
worldwide market for solar power. The company is rated A/stable by 
Standard & Poor’s and A2/stable by Moody’s. 
   
Proposed ADB  The proposed loan will be for up to the lower of $70 million equivalent 
Assistance  in baht (or dollars if for any reason Baht is not available) and 25% of 
project  costs.  In  the  event  that  ADB  cannot  effectively  fund  baht 
loans, or NED elects to arrange financing under an ADB partial credit 
guarantee, the proposed direct loan may be replaced by a partial 
credit guarantee issued by ADB to eligible lenders up to the lower of 
$70 million equivalent in baht and 25% of project costs.  The grant 
component of investments, amounting to $2 million, will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy

Financing Partnership Facility, comprising three clean energy funds 
whose aim is to help improve energy security in DMC's and decrease 
the rate of climate change. The grant funds will be administered by 
ADB and cover a portion of the contingency financing in the event 
that the project has to draw down contingency funds. The grant funds 
for contingency financing significantly reduce the risk of introducing 
PV technology on a large scale. 
   
Impact, Outcome  The project’s development impact will result from the demonstration 
and Benefits  effect  of  the  feasibility  and  sustainability  of  a  large-scale  private 
sector solar farm, a model that can be replicated by other private 
sector investors in Thailand and other developing member countries. 
Of all renewable energy sources in Thailand, solar energy has the 
most potential, possibly offering more than 50,000 MW of installed 
capacity. The project will be the first to demonstrate this unrealized 
potential.  The  project  and  its  anticipated  replication  will  diversify 
Thailand’s energy mix by adding renewable energy capacity, helping 
the  country  to  meet  its  target  of  obtaining  20.4%  of  its  primary 
commercial energy from renewable energy by 2022.  
   
Sponsors  The project is sponsored by the China Light and Power (CLP) Group, 
Mitsubishi, and the Electricity Generating Public Company. The CLP 
Group is a leading power utility in Asia with more than 30 power 
generation assets and distribution businesses throughout the Asia 
and Pacific region. The group is rated A−/stable by Standard & Poor’s 
and A2/stable by Moody’s. Mitsubishi, Japan’s largest general trading 
company, has managed businesses in a wide range of industries 
including energy, metals, machinery, chemicals, food, and general 
merchandise. Mitsubishi is rated A+/stable by Standard & Poor’s and 
A1/stable by Moody’s. The Electricity Generating Public Company is 
Thailand’s first and largest independent power producer.

Justification and  The justification for ADB’s assistance for the project is based on the 
ADB Value-Added  value that ADB can add to the project and its development impact 
and demonstration effects. The project merits ADB’s support because 
(i) ADB’s assistance is consistent with its country partnership strategy 
for Thailand 2007–2011 and country operations business plan, both 
of which are built on infrastructure development and environmentally 
sustainable  development  as  core  strategic  areas  of  partnership; 
(ii) the project supports the government’s strategy of diversifying its 
energy mix and securing its supply from domestic resources; (iii) the

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) either a 
proposed loan for the Solar Power Project up to the lesser of $70,000,000 equivalent in baht (or 
dollars if for any reason baht is not available) and 25% of project costs, from the ordinary capital 
resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) without government guarantee, or a partial 
credit  guarantee  issued  by  ADB  to  eligible  lenders  to  the  Natural  Energy  Development 
Company  (NED),  and  (ii)  the  proposed  administration  by  ADB  of  a  grant  component  of 
investment not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to the Natural Energy Development 
Company to be financed on a grant basis provided by the Clean Energy Fund under the Clean 
Energy Financing Partnership Facility1  to cover a portion of the contingency funding for the 
Solar Power Project. If approved, the project will constitute ADB’s third private sector investment 
in Thailand.  
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  Project Identification and Selection 
2.  To implement ADB’s Strategy 20202 and the Thailand country strategy by supporting 
clean energy projects, ADB worked with Thailand's Ministry of Finance to organize a seminar on 
the  financing  of  clean  energy  projects.  The  seminar  was  held  in  Bangkok  and  generated 
considerable interest among clean energy project sponsors and financial institutions. After the 
seminar, ADB identified the proposed project as one of the best in environmental sustainability, 
financial and technical feasibility, potential for carbon emission reduction, and demonstration 
impact.  
 
3.  Solar energy is an abundant resource throughout Thailand and can represent a potential 
of more than 50,000 megawatts (MW) in installed power capacity, 3 according to measurements 
of average solar irradiation over the last 20 years.4 The project will pioneer in demonstrating the 
commercial viability of large-scale private sector solar farms, a model that other private sector 
investors can then replicate in Thailand and elsewhere in the region. The photovoltaic power 
plant to be built under the project is expected to be one of the largest in the world.  
 
4.  This project and its potential demonstrational impact will benefit from a confluence of 
unique factors. The sound track record of China Light and Power (CLP), Mitsubishi, and the 
Electricity Generating Public Company (EGCO) (the project sponsors); the commitment of the 
Government of Thailand to clean energy through a supportive feed-in tariff; regulatory stability; 
and achievements of the solar industry worldwide—all these will mitigate the challenges that often 
go with large-scale solar projects. Moreover, ADB’s combination of financial products will bolster 
the viability of the project. Without prefinanced certified emission reductions (CERs) from ADB’s 
Future Carbon Fund (FCF), ADB’s long-term financing and the CEFPF’s GCI, the project is 
unlikely to meet the sponsors' minimum hurdle rates for implementation. The innovative structure 
of the grant component of investment (GCI) will significantly reduce the risk of introducing thin-film 
photovoltaic technology on a large scale by increasing the confidence of private sector investors

B.  Sector Overview 
5.  Thailand  is  a  large  consumer  of  electricity.  As  of  June  2009,  its  installed  power 
generation capacity was 28,482 MW, 70% of this from natural gas and 21% from coal and 
lignite. Its recent energy policy has stressed the importance of diversifying and securing sources 
of fuel for power generation. Overreliance on natural gas, coupled with exposure to oil price 
volatility, has magnified the country’s political and economic risk. The country continues to 
depend on imports as domestic demand for commercial primary energy outpaces the discovery 
of indigenous oil and gas.  
 
6.  Energy consumption in Thailand is growing much faster than the gross domestic product, 
reflecting the increasing share of energy investment. Energy consumption is responsible for 
more than 50% of the country’s greenhouse gas emissions.5 If unchecked, the rapid growth in 
energy consumption will increase carbon intensity in the economy. In the second revision of 
Thailand’s  Power  Development  Plan  20076,  published  in  2009,  the  Electricity  Generating 
Authority of Thailand (EGAT) projected a 4.9% average growth in net electricity generation 
demand and a 5.4% annual average increase in peak demand between 2008 and 2021. The 
energy technology choices Thailand makes now will therefore have important implications for 
climate change in the region in the long term.  
 
7.  Fortunately,  Thailand  has  abundant  renewable  energy  sources—biomass,  biogas, 
mini-hydro, solar, and wind. Using these domestic sources of renewable energy can boost 
Thailand’s energy security, save foreign exchange, and protect the country from global price 
fluctuations. As part of the strategy of diversifying the energy mix and promoting renewable 
energy, the government has prepared an Alternative Energy Development Plan7 (2008–2022) 
and set a target of 20.4% for primary commercial energy from renewable energy sources by 
2022. This implies a renewable energy capacity of 5,608 MW by 2022, a significant increase 
from the present 1,750 MW. 8  
 
8.   To  complement  its  renewable  energy  strategy  the  Ministry  of  Energy  is  advocating 
decentralized power generation mainly by supporting the country’s Small Power Producer (SPP) 
and Very Small Power Producer (VSPP) programs. The SPP program allows private developers 
to  build,  own,  and  operate  10–90 MW  power  projects  and  enter  into  power  purchase 
agreements (PPAs) with EGAT. Under the VSPP program, on the other hand, producers of up 
to 10 MW may sell power to the Metropolitan Electricity Authority (MEA) and the Provincial 
Electricity Authority (PEA). The country’s 118 VSPPs contribute less than 1% to total power 
generation, but the 60 SPPs account for 10%.9 Renewable energy SPPs and VSPPs can get

9.  Over  the  past  2  decades,  solar  power  has  become  more  and  more  economically 
attractive. Grid-connected solar photovoltaic generation systems are the fastest growing in the 
world: cumulative installed capacity grew by 50% yearly in 2006 and 2007 to 7.8 GW by the end 
of 2007.10 According to the Annual Energy Outlook 2009,11 the capacity costs of new plants 
using solar photovoltaics will be 37% lower by 2030 than the 2009 costs. At the same time, 
electricity from conventional sources will cost more to generate; thus, electricity prices will go up 
in places like Thailand that have large numbers of gas-fired power plants. By 2030, cheaper 
solar energy and higher-cost conventional power generation are expected to approach grid 
parity. With these trends converging, global installed solar capacity in 2020 could be 20–40 
times what it is today. 
 
10.  The project will be the first to demonstrate the capacity of large-scale solar projects to 
meet power needs in Thailand. After a large-scale private sector solar farm is shown to be 
feasible, other private sector investors can replicate the model in Thailand and other developing 
member countries (DMCs). Small-scale solar power has been around for many years, mainly 
providing energy to communities with no access to the national power grid. There are 32 
grid-connected solar rooftop projects with a generating capacity of 0.14 MW, and many small 
off-grid solar VSPP projects producing a total of 32 MW. In addition, a few small solar farms, 
sponsored by EGAT and the private sector, have a generating capacity of less than 2.2 MW.12 
Thailand’s Alternative Energy Policy projects solar power to grow from 34 MW to 500 MW by 
2022 (footnote 6). 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
1.  Consistency with ADB’s Strategy 2020 
11.  ADB’s  Strategy  2020  supports  environmentally  sustainable,  private  sector–assisted 
development in meeting the growing energy demand in the region, even as it capitalizes on 
ADB’s operating strengths in infrastructure development and finance, among other areas. The 
strategy seeks the expansion of environmentally friendly technologies, specifically for clean and 
efficient energy generation and use, and a larger role for the private sector in infrastructure 
financing through public–private partnerships. 
2.  Consistency with Country Strategy 
12.  The main constraints on sustainable economic growth are the central concerns of ADB’s 
partnership with Thailand. The country partnership strategy for Thailand 2007–201113 is directed 
at three core strategic areas—infrastructure, environmental sustainability, and capital markets. 
The  government’s  Alternative  Energy  Development  Plan,  approved  by  the  Cabinet  on 
28 January 2009, notes the immense potential of Thailand’s solar energy and the savings on 
energy imports that can be made through its use, with private sector investment.

3.  Consistency with Energy Policy 
13.  ADB’s  Energy  Policy 14  gives  emphasis  to  investments  in  energy  efficiency  and 
renewable energy projects, and in wider access to energy. In 2013, ADB will raise its clean 
energy investment target to $2 billion a year from the present $1 billion, in a bid to speed up 
low-carbon  growth  and  reduce  greenhouse  gas  emissions  in  the  region.  The  policy  also 
underscores ADB’s continued financial and technical support for projects that qualify for carbon 
credits under the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) of the Kyoto Protocol. The proposed 
project is expected to benefit from the prefinancing of CERs by ADB's Carbon Market Initiative 
(CMI). The CMI team has been working on the CDM component with the project sponsors, in 
parallel with the ADB loan discussions. 
III.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Description 
  1.   The Borrower and the Sponsors   
14.  The project is sponsored by a unique partnership that combines regional leadership, 
operating and technical expertise, and strong local presence. The borrower, NED, is a joint 
venture in which the sponsors—CLP Thailand Renewables (a wholly owned subsidiary of CLP 
Holdings), Diamond Generating Asia (a wholly owned subsidiary of Mitsubishi), and EGCO—
each hold a 33.33% share. NED, headquartered in Bangkok, has the primary aim of developing, 
owning, managing, and operating renewable energy projects in the region.15  
 
15.  CLP Thailand Renewables, established as an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary of CLP 
Holdings Limited (CLP), will hold a 33.3% stake in NED. CLP is one of the leading power utilities 
in Asia with more than 30 power generation assets and distribution businesses throughout the 
Asia and Pacific region. CLP has equity in about 6,400 MW of generating assets in Australia, 
India, Thailand, and Taipei,China. In Hong Kong, China, CLP operates a vertically integrated 
electricity  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  business  with  an  installed  capacity  of 
6,908 MW and a transmission capacity of 12,000 kilometers (km). It supplies electricity to about 
80% of the population of Hong Kong, China. CLP is listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. 
CLP  has  a  strong  commitment  to  renewable  energy.  The  group,  in  2004,  set  a  target  of 
generating 5% of its output from renewable sources by 2010 and met the target 3 years ahead 
of time. It has also expanded into solar energy through its Australian subsidiary, TRUenergy, 
which is developing a solar power station in Melbourne.  
 
16.  CLP is rated A−/stable/A−2 by Standard & Poor’s and A2/stable by Moody’s. This rating 
reflects the group’s strong liquidity, favorable regulatory environment, good liability management, 
and  significant  financial  flexibility.  CLP  plans  to  increase  its  financial  leverage,  but  it  has 
maintained good access to the capital markets despite tightening global financial markets. 
CLP’s market capitalization is about HK$126.6 billion ($16.3 billion) and the group revenue in 
2008 was about HK$54.3 billion ($7.0 billion) and net income HK$10.4 billion ($1.3 billion).

20.  EGCO  is  regarded  as  a  company  with  high  corporate  governance  standards  and

   2.  Project Design 
21.  The project entails the construction of a 55 MWp solar generation plant in the Lopburi 
province of Central Thailand. The development and implementation of the SPP will be covered 
by a 5-year, automatically renewable PPA between EGAT and NED under the SPP Program. 
EGAT will purchase all energy output of the plant up to 55 MW, the maximum defined in the 
PPA. The project will use innovative thin-film photovoltaic technology and is expected to be one 
of the largest solar photovoltaic projects in the world. In addition, the project is working with ADB 
for the prefinancing of CERs under ADB’s CMI.

2.  Selected Photovoltaic Technology  
33.  A solar cell is an electronic device which directly converts the sunlight into electricity 
through the "photoelectric effect" thus the solar cell produces both current and voltage to 
generate  electric  power.  This  process  requires  a  special  material,  a  photosensitive 
semiconductor enriched with other complementary elements, in which the absorption of light 
raises their electrons to a higher energy state. These electrons move from the solar cell into an 
external electrical circuit, dissipate their energy there, return unloaded to the cell and begin the 
process over again. The silicon material used for solar cells can be single-crystalline, multi-
crystalline, poly-crystalline or amorphous.  The two main categories of technology are defined 
by the choice of the semiconductor—either crystalline silicon in wafer form or thin films of other 
materials. 
 
(i)  Monocrystalline  silicon.  This  is  the  most  efficient  technology  to  date.  The 
photovoltaic cell is made from single crystals of silicon. Research cells have 
reached nearly 28% efficiency; commercial modules of single-crystal cells, more 
than 18%. 
 
(ii)  Multi-crystalline silicon. Multi-crystalline silicon is manufactured more cheaply 
than monocrystalline silicon, with the cells being cut from an ingot of melted and 
recrystallized silicon. These cells are less efficient than single-crystal silicon cells. 
Research  cells  approach  24%  efficiency,  and  commercial  modules,  16% 
efficiency. 
 
(iii)  Thin  film.  Various  materials,  such  as  amorphous  silicon,  cadmium  telluride 
(CdTe),  and  copper  indium  diselenide  (CIS),  are  used  to  make  thin-film

34.  The sponsors have selected thin-film photovoltaic technology after in-depth analysis of 
local conditions, on-site measurements, and competitive bidding. Amorphous silicon thin-film 
solar cells will be used in the project. Thin-film technology was selected for the following 
reasons.  Thin-film  solar  cells  are  relatively  lower  in  production  cost  than  other  types  of 
photovoltaic  cells.  Moreover,  thin-film  photovoltaic  cells  are  better  at  absorbing  sunlight 
approaching  the  cell  from  different  directions  and  at  maintaining  efficiency  under  different 
irradiations.  Therefore,  thin-film  photovoltaic  technology  better  suits  Thailand’s  climatic 
environment  (irradiation  profile)  because  it  does  not  require  near-perfect  solar  conditions. 
Clouds and overcast conditions at times create diffuse light, which cannot be concentrated but 
still produces energy on thin-film photovoltaic panels. Besides irradiation, thin-film solar cells 
offer better relative performance in climates with higher average temperatures. In general, solar 
cells become less able to convert the solar energy into electrical power (conversion efficiency) 
as the temperature increases. Thin-film solar cells, however, decrease in conversion efficiency 
more slowly than other solar cells.  
 
35.  The  market  for  thin-film  solar  cells  has  been  growing  rapidly.  In  recent  years, 
manufacturers of thin-film solar cells have brought production costs down and tried to achieve 
competitive strengths through more advanced thin-film technology. This is evidenced by the 
rapid growth in market share of thin-film solar cells in the United States, to 44% in 2006 from 
less  than  10%  in  2003.  The  European  Photovoltaic  Industry  Association  expects  annual 
production capacity for thin-film technology to double to more than 4 GW by 2010. Overall, solar 
photovoltaic  installations  reached  a  record  high  of  15  GW  in  2008.  Europe’s  installed 
photovoltaic  capacity  of  9 GW  is  65%  of  this  total,  Japan’s  2.1 GW  is  15%,  and  the 
United States’ 1.2 GW is 8%.

project is designed to have a gross generation capacity of 73 megawatts (MWp) of direct current. 
The alternating current output will be about 57.9 MW, of which about 2.9 MW will be consumed 
internally and the remaining 55 MW will be sold to the Electricity Generating Authority  of 
Thailand (EGAT) through a 115 kilovolt (kV) transmission line to a Provincial Electricity Authority 
(PEA) substation about 15 km away. The project construction is expected to begin in the second 
quarter of 2010 and will take about 24 months to complete.  
 
2.  The Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment does not require an environmental 
impact  assessment  for  solar  power  projects.  Nevertheless,  NED  commissioned  a  local 
consulting firm2 to undertake an environmental and social assessment (ESA) of the project to 
ensure that the project will be absolutely environmentally sound and acceptable to the local 
communities.  The  ESA  was  conducted  from  August  2009  to  early  December  2009.  This 
summary  initial  environmental  examination  (SIEE)  document  summarizes  the  findings  and 
conclusions of the ESA. The SIEE was prepared for the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in full 
compliance  with  its  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  for  category  B3 projects  and  the 
government’s environmental policy, guidelines, and requirements, as well as the World Bank 
Group’s Environmental, Health, and Safety Guidelines (EHS guidelines).

C.  Description of the Environment 
1.  Project Location 
5.  The project site covers 1,100 rais (about 176 hectares) of privately owned agricultural 
land, located next to Rural Road No. 3014 and surrounded by agricultural land. The project site 
has no irrigation system and is used mainly for planting cash crops, particularly cassava and 
maize, and also eucalyptus trees. Some parts are unattended land covered by grasses, bushes, 
and shrubs.  
2.  Physical Environment 
6.  The project site has a humid tropical climate with annual average temperatures ranging 
from 23.6°C to 33.7°C, average annual rainfall of 1,123.8 millimeters, and annual average 
relative humidity of 71%. Soil in the project site is of low to medium fertility. The project site is in 
a low-seismic-risk region. 
 
7.  Surface water at the project site is drained by two small, unnamed natural watercourses. 
One watercourse traverses the western part of the project site in a south–north direction, and 
drains water into a natural canal. Another watercourse traverses the eastern part of the project 
site in a south–north direction, and drains water into another canal.  
 
8.  The project site still has good environmental quality as it has no nearby industries or 
urban communities. The two watercourses in the project site are still virtually unpolluted, as 
indicated by the low levels of biological oxygen demand, chemical oxygen demand, and oil and 
grease. The dust level in the ambient air, measured as total suspended particulates (TSP), is 
still lower than the national standard of 0.33 mg/Nm3 (24-hour average). Ambient noise levels in 
the three nearest communities are below the national standards 24-hour not exceeding 70 dBA 
per 24 hours, and maximum not exceeding 115 dBA. 
3.  Biological Environment 
9.  The project site is not located in or near a sensitive ecosystem. An ecological survey of 
the project site confirmed the absence of unique or ecologically significant flora and fauna. The 
nearest wildlife sanctuary, Sublanka, is about 60 km away.

Appendix 1  21 
4.  Socioeconomic Environment 
10.  The project site has no communities. Two subdistricts, Wang Plerng and Khao Laem, 
are within a 5 km radius of the project site. Wang Plerng has 13 villages with a total population 
of 7,536 living in 1,963 households (April 2009 records). Khao Laem has 8 villages with a total 
population  of  3,298  living  in  940  households  (April  2009  records).  Barn  Chonmuang  in 
Wang  Plerng Subdistrict, about 650 meters away, is the community nearest to the project site. 
There are no indigenous peoples living within or close to the project site. About 90% of the 
households rely on agriculture as their main source of income.  
  5.  Historical and Cultural Value 
11.  The project site and the surrounding areas have no important historical or cultural sites. 
There are no records of archeological findings. 
D.  Environmental Impact and Mitigation Measures 
1.  Impact during Construction 
12.  The project will involve only minor civil, mechanical, and electrical works taking place at 
many locations within a vast project site. The site preparation will involve only minor leveling, 
and thus will not significantly change the drainage pattern. The transportation of construction 
materials and project equipment will require about 15 truck trips per day during the working 
period  of  8  hours.  Considering  the  nature  and  scope  of  the  construction  works  and  the 
ecological  insensitivity  of  the  project  site,  it  is  certain  that  only  minor  and  manageable 
environmental disturbances will be created during construction, with minimum impact on nearby 
communities and the natural environment. Environmental disturbances during construction will 
be small and transient, such as dust, noise, incremental traffic loads on the roads, and gaseous 
emissions created by trucks and heavy construction equipment. Estimates of the incremental 
increases in ambient dust and noise levels during construction were made and were found to be 
marginal. The ambient dust level will increase by 23.51 micrograms per cubic meter and noise 
by 0.7 dBA at the nearest community. 
 
13.  As the 15 km, 115 kV transmission line will be constructed within the corridor of an 
existing 22 kV transmission line of PEA, there will be no need for any land acquisition or 
clearance. The transmission line will therefore create minimum transient environmental and 
social impact. 
 
14.  The construction will require not more than 500 workers, who will reside outside the 
project site. No groundwater will be tapped at the project site as the project site has low 
groundwater potential. The water required for construction (concrete mixing) and consumption 
will be brought in from outside sources. Domestic wastewater generated by the construction 
workers would not be more than 20 cubic meters per day  and will be treated either in a small 
centralized package treatment plant or by individual septic tanks, one for each toilet. 
 
15.  The nature of the construction works indicates that no toxic or hazardous materials will 
be used, apart from fuel oils for vehicles, which will be properly stored. Construction wastes will 
be sorted out by the contractors for recycling. The residual wastes will be properly handled by 
the relevant municipal units for waste disposal.

22  Appendix 1 
2.  Impact during Operations 
16.  Unlike thermal power plants, the operation of the project solar power plant will have 
negligible environmental impact on the site during operation. There will be no waste products, 
no requirements for cooling, no moving parts, no noise, and no impact on flora and fauna. The 
largest impact could be visual. However, as the project site and the surrounding areas have no 
natural  beauty,  visual  impairment  would  not  be  a  problem.  With  an  old  design  of  solar 
photovoltaic arrays, reflected sunlight may cause problems if the system is close to a road and 
is facing in a direction in which the reflected sunlight may cause problems. This problem will not 
occur in this project as its solar photovoltaic panels are of new design, which can absorb 
sunlight and eliminate sunlight reflections.  
 
17.  The project will use transformers of forced-oil and forced-air-cool designs, which do not 
use polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB). Therefore, there will be no PCB disposal problem.  
 
18.  Only about 40 staff will operate the project facilities. Domestic wastes generated by this 
small number of people could be readily handled by conventional practices. 
E.  Social Impact 
19.  The project has no resettlement or indigenous peoples (IPs) issues. In August 2009, the 
project entered into a land purchase option agreement4 with all 11 landowners to purchase the 
land on a willing-buyer-willing-seller basis, valid for 8 months with a 4-month extension period. 
The landowners will be allowed to harvest their crops before the project starts construction, in 
line with the requirements of the ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) for negotiated 
settlement. Only one owner lives on his land and will be allowed to stay on and be employed by 
the project. Therefore, there will be no relocation issue. The project site has no people identified 
as IPs. The project is therefore expected to be classified as category C for both involuntary 
resettlement and IPs. 
F.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Management Plan 
20.  As  the  project  is  virtually  environmentally  benign,  the  institutional  requirements  for 
environmental management during construction and operation will be minimal. Nevertheless, 
the project plans to apply for environmental accreditation through ISO14000.  
 
21.  During construction, the contractors will be contractually mandated to minimize transient 
environmental disturbances, using known conventional methods such as water spraying to 
minimize dust, the imposition of speed limits on vehicles in the project site, the provision of an 
adequate number of bathrooms and toilets for construction workers, the proper management of 
domestic wastes (particularly the disposal of food wastes), and the imposition of sanitation and 
work  safety  rules  and  regulations.  The  project  manager  of  NED  will  closely  monitor  the 
contractors’ compliance with the environmental and safety clauses of the contracts. TSP levels 
in the ambient air and noise levels in the nearest communities will be occasionally monitored 
during construction.

if the project is implemented.

22.  During the project operation, environmental management will mostly involve domestic 
wastes created by about 40 staff. This matter can be readily handled.

subdistricts. In addition, a field survey was also carried out to collect basic socioeconomic

24.  As  the  project  will  have  no  significant  environmental  and  social  impact,  the  local 
communities  and  community  leaders  did  not  oppose  the  project.  They,  however,  sought 
assistance in community development and support for community cultural events.  
H.  Findings and Recommendations 
25.  The ESA findings establish that the project site is a relatively infertile agricultural land, is 
not located in a sensitive ecosystem, and has no historical or cultural value. This nature of the 
project site, coupled with the clean nature of solar power generation, confirms that the project 
will not cause any significant, lasting environmental and social impact. Only minor and transient 
environmental disturbances will be generated in the project site during construction, and will be 
minimized through established control measures to be implemented by the contractors. It is 
therefore recommended that the project be considered environmentally and socially feasible, 
and that the IEE be considered adequate to justify environmental and social clearance of the 
project. There is no need for further analysis, and the environmental and social assessment of 
the project is considered complete. 
I.  Conclusions 
26.  It is concluded that the project has no further environmental and social issues to follow 
up, and will fully comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).
